items.title: Write epub to database
items.body: Using epub.write_epub is it possible to write the epub to some database?

items.title: Trouble with section/subchapters
items.body:
Is there a way to add subchapters in section and they'll start after each other? If I do c1.content += c2.content it works, however I can't link c2 to TOC. 
When I add c1 and c2 separately TOC works fine, but c2 starts in a new page instead after c1.
I've tried css page-break-before/after:avoid but that's seems not working.

items.title: Ampersand escaping disabling
items.body:
I have some URLs that contain plain "&" characters. The ampersand is being escaped when adding an `EpubHtml` chapter to the book and generating the epub. The responsible server doesn't accept the escaped variant "&" when following the link.

Maybe that happens because of using an xml parser for the content transformations?
Not sure if xhtml or epub specification require this escaping...

Maybe related: https://bytes.com/topic/python/answers/827193-urls-ampersands

Possible solution: Plugin that searches for certain URLs and I escaped them...

items.title: EPUB2 error while exporting
items.body:
Hi,

I am getting this error while using the Booktype installation which uses ebooklib as core package. Strangely, this is not happening with EPUB3 format and it is perfectly exporting.

When I am publishing using EPUB2 format, I am getting this error : KeyError : 'package_direction'.

  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/celery/app/trace.py", line 375, $
    R = retval = fun(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/celery/app/trace.py", line 632, $
    return self.run(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/src/booktype/lib/booktype/apps/convert/tasks.py", line 50, i$
    return func(request, *args, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/src/booktype/lib/booktype/apps/convert/tasks.py", line 66, i$
    result = run_conversion(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/src/booktype/lib/booktype/convert/runner.py", line 58, in ru$
    conversion_result = converter.convert(book, output)
  File "/usr/local/src/booktype/lib/booktype/convert/epub/converter.py", line 1$
    epub_writer.write()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/ebooklib/epub.py", line 1223, in$
    self._write_opf_file()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/ebooklib/epub.py", line 858, in $
    if self.book.direction and self.options['package_direction']:
KeyError: 'package_direction'

Please help!
Thanks.
Santanu

items.title: Autoscroll the toc from the content
items.body:
I notice that all samples toc with `epub.Section` in this repo have the issue below:

<details>
<summary>View image</summary>

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40143136/66503491-f46c3800-eaf9-11e9-8cac-501ccdac69e7.png)

</details>

That will be really inconvenient if the toc is very long, since it will cost us a lot of time to scroll the toc again and again.

I have tried using `epub.Link` to replace the former `c2` which is  `epub.EpubHtml`, but that doesn't help

<details>
<summary> code in the repo samples </summary>

```
    book.toc = (epub.Link('intro.xhtml', 'Introduction', 'intro'),
                 (epub.Section('Languages'),
                 (c2),))
                )
```

</details>

```
    book.toc = (epub.Link('intro.xhtml', 'Introduction', 'intro'),
                 (epub.Section('Languages'),
                 (epub.Link('about.xhtml', c2.title, 'intro2'),))
                )
```

But when there is no section in toc, the focus in toc is ok


<details>
<summary>View image</summary>

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40143136/66504199-3d70bc00-eafb-11e9-97d0-3463ce003554.png)


</details>

items.title: How to pack images into epub
items.body:
Temporarily, I use `book.setcover()` to pack images into epub. ``` # add cover image book.set_cover("image.jpg", open('cover.jpg', 'rb').read()) book.set_cover("image2.jpg", open('try.jpg', 'rb').read()) ``` After unzipping the epub file, part of it looks like ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40143136/66481299-2e761380-ead3-11e9-9b29-41a7d0ee688c.png) And it works
View image ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40143136/66482177-ff60a180-ead4-11e9-9699-c34810d4c421.png)
I have gone through all the samples in this repo, but didn't find a similar example. So now I have two questions: 1. I wonder if there is other way to implement that. 2. If I try something like ``` # add cover image book.set_cover("image.jpg", open('cover.jpg', 'rb').read()) book.set_cover("./images/image2.jpg", open('try.jpg', 'rb').read()) c2.content='

About this book

' ``` I won't see `images2.jpg`, what's the possible reason?

What the epub file looks like after unzipping ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40143136/66482655-ffad6c80-ead5-11e9-8251-82b0b6fca48c.png) The `images` folder contains `image2.jpg` and I can see those images by accessing `about.xhtml` but I couldn't see `image2.jpg` through epub.
Here is my working code if you have images named `cover.jpg` and `try.jpg`
View code ``` # coding=utf-8 from ebooklib import epub if __name__ == '__main__': book = epub.EpubBook() # add metadata book.set_identifier('sample123456') book.set_title('Sample book') book.set_language('en') book.add_author('Aleksandar Erkalovic') # add cover image book.set_cover("image.jpg", open('cover.jpg', 'rb').read()) book.set_cover("image2.jpg", open('try.jpg', 'rb').read()) # intro chapter c1 = epub.EpubHtml(title='Introduction', file_name='intro.xhtml', lang='hr') c1.content=u'

Introduction

Introduction paragraph where i explain what is happening.

' # about chapter c2 = epub.EpubHtml(title='About this book', file_name='about.xhtml') c2.content='

About this book

Helou, this is my book! There are many books, but this one is mine.

' # add chapters to the book book.add_item(c1) book.add_item(c2) # create table of contents # - add manual link # - add section # - add auto created links to chapters book.toc = (epub.Link('intro.xhtml', 'Introduction', 'intro'), (epub.Section('Languages'), (c1, c2)) ) # add navigation files book.add_item(epub.EpubNcx()) book.add_item(epub.EpubNav()) # define css style style = ''' @namespace epub "http://www.idpf.org/2007/ops"; body { font-family: Cambria, Liberation Serif, Bitstream Vera Serif, Georgia, Times, Times New Roman, serif; } h2 { text-align: left; text-transform: uppercase; font-weight: 200; } ol { list-style-type: none; } ol > li:first-child { margin-top: 0.3em; } nav[epub|type~='toc'] > ol > li > ol { list-style-type:square; } nav[epub|type~='toc'] > ol > li > ol > li { margin-top: 0.3em; } ''' # add css file nav_css = epub.EpubItem(uid="style_nav", file_name="style/nav.css", media_type="text/css", content=style) book.add_item(nav_css) # create spin, add cover page as first page book.spine = ['cover', 'nav', c1, c2] # create epub file epub.write_epub('test.epub', book, {}) ``` That code will throw a warning ``` Warning (from warnings module): File "C:\Program Files\Python36\lib\zipfile.py", line 1349 return self._open_to_write(zinfo, force_zip64=force_zip64) UserWarning: Duplicate name: 'EPUB/cover.xhtml' ``` But that doesn't matter.

items.title: How to create subsection?
items.body:
With the syntax like ``` book.toc = (epub.Link('intro.xhtml', 'Introduction', 'intro'), ( epub.Section('Languages1'), (c1, c2), ), ( epub.Section('Languages2'), (c3, ), ), ) ``` I can create multi sections
View image ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40143136/66459620-fd341e00-eaa7-11e9-9d19-00ec76b3f69a.png)
I want something like ``` 1 1.1 1.1.1 1.1.2 ``` So I tried syntax like ``` book.toc = (epub.Link('intro.xhtml', 'Introduction', 'intro'), ( epub.Section('Languages3'), ( epub.Section('Languages4'), (c1, c2), ), ), ) ``` But I got ``` TypeError: 'EpubHtml' object is not iterable ``` I go through all the samples in the repo but didn't find an example about that. So is it possible to do that? My whole code is below:
View code ``` from ebooklib import epub book = epub.EpubBook() # add metadata book.set_identifier('sample123456') book.set_title('Sample book') book.set_language('en') book.add_author('Aleksandar Erkalovic') # intro chapter c1 = epub.EpubHtml(title='Introduction', file_name='intro.xhtml', lang='en') c1.content=u'

Introduction

Introduction paragraph where i explain what is happening.

' # about chapter c2 = epub.EpubHtml(title='About this book', file_name='about.xhtml') c2.content='

About this book

Helou, this is my book! There are many books, but this one is mine.

' # add chapters to the book book.add_item(c1) book.add_item(c2) c_list = ['nav', c1, c2] for i in range(3, 9): c = epub.EpubHtml(title='%s'%i, file_name='%s.xhtml'%i) c.content='

%s

'%i book.add_item(c) c_list.append(c) # create table of contents # - add section # - add auto created links to chapters book.toc = (epub.Link('intro.xhtml', 'Introduction', 'intro'), ( epub.Section('Languages1'), (c1, c2), ), ( epub.Section('Languages2'), (c_list[3], ), ), ( epub.Section('Languages3'), ( epub.Section('Languages4'), (c_list[4], c_list[5]), ), ), ) # add navigation files book.add_item(epub.EpubNcx()) book.add_item(epub.EpubNav()) # define css style style = ''' @namespace epub "http://www.idpf.org/2007/ops"; body { font-family: Cambria, Liberation Serif, Bitstream Vera Serif, Georgia, Times, Times New Roman, serif; } h2 { text-align: left; text-transform: uppercase; font-weight: 200; } ol { list-style-type: none; } ol > li:first-child { margin-top: 0.3em; } nav[epub|type~='toc'] > ol > li > ol { list-style-type:square; } nav[epub|type~='toc'] > ol > li > ol > li { margin-top: 0.3em; } ''' # add css file nav_css = epub.EpubItem(uid="style_nav", file_name="style/nav.css", media_type="text/css", content=style) book.add_item(nav_css) # create spine book.spine = c_list # create epub file epub.write_epub('test.epub', book, {}) ```

items.body:
when I add a str value to c.content, I having a error:
```
lxml.etree.ParserError: Document is empty
```
code:
```python
temp = "<html><head>" + title + "</head>" + "<body>" + text + "</body></html>"
c.content = temp
```

`tile` and `text` are all str value
when I changed the code like this:

```
temp = "<html><head>" + title + "</head>" + "<body>" + text + "</body></html>"
c.content = "|"+temp+"|"
```
It's ok. Why?

    book.get_items_of_type(ebooklib.ITEM_COVER)

I have search for quite a while, and I haven't found any useful information about the cover standard. So according to my knowledge, I have change this code as following in order to get cover Image each time.

    if 'cover-image' in properties or 'cover.jpg' in r.get('id'):

- <http://idpf.org/epub/31>

items.title: Load images inside html
items.body:
Hello there!
Suppose I have a HTML Page with images. 
I get that page, process with bs4 to check for images. If images are found, I download them. 
Problem Is, how to add them inside the epub's xhtml page in the same place they were in the earlier HTML page ? Are there any native methods for this ? If yes, how to use them ?

**My thoughts:** 

- If I have to change the `src`, then where to point at ? Because if epub is moved from original place, any external `src` location will be invalid.

- Do i have to use `book.add_item()` method ? Can you explain how to use it ?

Thanks.

items.title: Readfile method fails on MS Windows
items.body:
The issue is fairly simple, we zipfile module uses / as directory separator and we use os.path.normpath which uses directory separator default to the OS. In the case of MS Windows it is \ character. Because zipfile module requires / it would fail.

We need independent normpath function.

items.title: Sample file 05_plugins_create files on Python 3+
items.body: It uses *urlparse* module which only exists on Python 2+ and not 3+.

items.title: Parsing files fails because of page-list
items.body: It assumes it will always find page-list elements in the nav.xhtml file. It will fail if it does not.

items.title: epub:type is not properly extracted
items.body:
When created nav.xhtml file we extract all elements with defined attribute epub:type. We extract the id or text and insert it at the end of the nav.xhtml file as a list. This fails when you do not have defined id or text is not defined.

We need to check the values and look for the alternative page name, for instance h1 elements and etc.

items.title: Wrong rules in MANIFEST.in
items.body:
The rules in `MANIFEST.in` are incomplete and wrong.

You should have:

```
include *.txt
recursive-include docs *.py
recursive-include docs *.rst
recursive-include docs Makefile
recursive-include samples *.jpg
recursive-include samples *.md
recursive-include samples *.py
```

But you also need to:

- rename `CHANGES.TXT` to `CHANGES.txt`,
- rename `docs/_static/README` to `docs/_static/README.rst`,
- delete `MANIFEST`.

To check your manifest file, activate your `virtualenv` and run:

    check-manifest

items.title: Bad rendering of README on PyPi
items.body:
The rendering of `README` on PyPi in wrong. The reason is simple: markdown is not yet supported.

To see the problem online, check the Project page here:

- On PyPi: https://pypi.python.org/pypi/EbookLib
- On Warehouse: https://pypi.org/project/EbookLib/

If you want to check your README before registering on PyPi, you can use [`readme-render`](https://github.com/pypa/readme_renderer).

For instance, activate your `virtualenv` and run:

    pip install readme_renderer
    python setup.py check -r -s

You get:

    running check
    warning: Check: :52: (ERROR/3) Unexpected indentation.
    
    warning: Check: Invalid markup which will not be rendered on PyPI.
    
    error: Please correct your package.

One way to fix that is to add some restructuredText markups in your `README.md`, for instance a "::" before each code block.

Example:

```markdown
Reading
-------

::

    import ebooklib
    from ebooklib import epub

    book = epub.read_epub('test.epub')

    for image in book.get_items_of_type(ebooklib.ITEM_IMAGE):
        print image
```

items.title: Get body content calls get content for no reason
items.body: Inside of get_body_content we call get_content and never use the return value but rather use content of self.content.

items.title: Initialize mimetype library only when it is being used
items.body: Mimetype library is being initialised first time the epub is loaded. What we really need is do it only first time when it is used and maybe locate everything in the utils module.

items.title: Add .ttf extension to the list of font files
items.body: We only have .otf and .woff as font extensions. We should also add .ttf for True Type fonts.

items.title: spine: text orientation attribute
items.body:
Hi and thanks, ebooklib works like a charm. My questions: is there a way to change `spine` and `body` attributes to support text orientation from right to left needed for RTL languages? Currently the following has to be modified _manually_ after creation of the epub, inside the zip file. In **EPUB/content.opf**:

`<spine toc=“mcx” page-progression-direction="rtl">`

and in main content / chapter

`<body dir=“rtl”>`

items.title: EpubReader throws Exception if OPF's <metadata> tag contains XML comments
items.body:
Just wanted to share some information about an error I faced when parsing the metadata of an epub file using EpubReader.

I was using ebooklib v0.15. When the error happens, the library throws the following exception:

```
'cython_function_or_method' object has no attribute 'rfind'
```

Checked the source code, and confirmed that it comes from the following code:

```
class EpubReader(object):
    ...
    def _load_metadata(self):
        ...
        for t in metadata:
            if not etree.iselement(t):
                continue
            if t.tag == default_ns + 'meta':
                ...
            else:
                tag = t.tag[t.tag.rfind('}') + 1:]    // From here
```

The reason is that `etree.iselement(t)` seems to treat both comments and tags as elements, e.g. it returns true even if `t` is an XML comment.

I was using python 2.7.10 on Mac 10.11 with lxml v3.6.2.

I checked the issue history here but seems no one else met this issue before, is it only me because of my environment?

It seems to me that this is an issue of the lxml library. And I tried to upgrade my lxml to v3.6.3 but failed to do that (couldn't fix some error during the installation).

In case it's a common issue, it would be better that ebooklib handles it internally. That's why I created this ticket.

Thanks,
Wendong

items.title: Error when using set_cover
items.body:
Hi, 

I'm using Python 3.5 and when I try to set a cover, I get the following stacktrace:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./main.py", line 181, in <module>
    main()
  File "./main.py", line 128, in main
    epub.write_epub(os.path.join(directory, bookname + ".epub"), book, {})
  File "/home/****/anaconda3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/ebooklib/epub.py", line 1163, in write_epub
    epub.write()
  File "/home/****/anaconda3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/ebooklib/epub.py", line 857, in write
    self._write_items()
  File "/home/****/anaconda3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/ebooklib/epub.py", line 848, in _write_items
    self.out.writestr('%s/%s' % (self.book.FOLDER_NAME, item.file_name), item.get_content())
  File "/home/****/anaconda3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/ebooklib/epub.py", line 298, in get_content
    tree = parse_string(super(EpubCoverHtml, self).get_content())
  File "/home/****/anaconda3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/ebooklib/utils.py", line 30, in parse_string
    tree = etree.parse(io.BytesIO(s))
TypeError: a bytes-like object is required, not 'str'
```

The problem seems to be in line 456:

```
tree = parse_string(super(EpubCoverHtml, self).get_content())
```

`super(EpubCoverHtml, self).get_content()` simply returns an empty string, changing it to

```
tree = parse_string(super().get_content())
```

seems to work for me, although I'm not sure if it's  viable patch. On a sidenote, this error also appears when trying to execute sample number 2

items.title: Update list of authors
items.body: We have many contributions from different authors but list of authors has never been updated.

items.title: Fix docstrings
items.body: Cover as much as possible docstrings for the current code.

items.title: Change README.md to have ASCII encoding
items.body: There are some issues with setup.py file and Python 2 and Python 3 encoding issues. The best would be just to make README.md file to use ASCII encoding. That would fix all the issues plus there will be no issues because of it.

items.title: Underline tag gets deleted
items.body: Plugin for cleaning contents eats underline tag. We should just remove <u> tag from the list of not allowed tags.

items.title: Sections are not pointing to any specific content
items.body: Sections are not pointing to any specific content at all. They are just blank. What we should do is male it possible to sections to point at the specific chapter.

items.title: Error to create cover
items.body:
Just try to run the sample to create the cover, because my project does not work and I've noticed that when I download yours either, and just saw this error log, I use python 3.4, everything works correctly except cover.

items.title: Can't display cover on first page
items.body:
Hi,
First, thank you for this great lib.
I don't manage to display the cover on first page. Is there any solution / option for that ? Do I need to add a page manually?
Thanks
G

items.title: Epub2 guide types do not map completely to epub3 landmark types
items.body: For instance 'notes' =='rearnotes'  and 'text' == 'bodymatter'.

items.title: Set unique metadata function
items.body: Add metadata if metadata with this identifier does not already exist, otherwise update existing metadata.

items.title: In the sample file read cover image in binary mode
items.body: Cover image is read in text mode, instead of binary.

items.title: Ignore vim swapfiles
items.body: Just add this "*.swp" to the .gitignore file.

items.title: Mimetypes library isn't aware of xhtml
items.body: Mimetypes library isn't aware of xhtml (as of 08/11/2014). Just add xhtml mimetype to the mimetypes module.

items.title: Unicode error when reading setup.py
items.body:
Hello,

I was getting error on ARM platform when trying to install ebooklib from pypi. Line 13 in `setup.py`, `long_description` should be with encoding specified. With this it works fine:

```
long_description = open('README.md', encoding="utf8").read()
```

Thank you

items.title: Handle sections with content
items.body:
We did not support sections in Table Of Contents without a content.

This fix was send by Pull Request #65 by the community user. If item in the Table Of Contents is EpubHtml object we will not create empty link to it.

items.title: Add support for the bindings element
items.body:
This was received with PR #65 from the community member.

Detailed specification for the bindings element is here - http://www.idpf.org/epub/30/spec/epub30-publications.html#sec-bindings-elem

items.title: Fix typo www.ipdf.org in the creation of OPF file
items.body:
Fix 'rendition: http://www.ipdf.org/vocab/rendition/#'; to 'rendition: …
…http://www.idpf.org/vocab/rendition/#'; when writing OPF file

items.title: Typo in idpf URI namespace
items.body:
After exporting an EPUB, the content.opf file contains:

xmlns="http://www.idpf.org/2007/opf"

which like http://www.idpf.org/2007/ops is a 404, and:

prefix="rendition: http://www.ipdf.org/vocab/rendition/#"

which is not a valid domain (ipdf.org versus idpf.org).

See ebooklib/epub.py lines 45, 47, 67, 69, 73 and 546.

items.title: embed <script> instead of <link> for javascripts
items.body:
As reported by @rdhyee:

I found that items of type ebooklib.ITEM_SCRIPT were added as <link> elements. This changes the embedding to <script>.

The changes here were the minimal ones I needed to work for my case.

items.title: Add basic documentation
items.body: Merge basic documentation from http://github.com/Booktype/ebooklib/ repository.

items.title: ePub extraction not working on Windows
items.body:
Using `os.path` for reading zip items is problematic on Windows because it uses backslash as a path separator (`os.sep` is `'\\'`).

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  ...
  File "D:\tmp\ebooklib\ebooklib\epub.py", line 1172, in read_epub
    book = reader.load()
  File "D:\tmp\ebooklib\ebooklib\epub.py", line 891, in load
    self._load()
  File "D:\tmp\ebooklib\ebooklib\epub.py", line 1150, in _load
    self._load_opf_file()
  File "D:\tmp\ebooklib\ebooklib\epub.py", line 1128, in _load_opf_file
    self._load_manifest()
  File "D:\tmp\ebooklib\ebooklib\epub.py", line 990, in _load_manifest
    ei.content = self.read_file(os.path.join(self.opf_dir, ei.file_name))
  File "D:\tmp\ebooklib\ebooklib\epub.py", line 897, in read_file
    return self.zf.read(name)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\zipfile.py", line 931, in read
    return self.open(name, "r", pwd).read()
  File "C:\Python27\lib\zipfile.py", line 957, in open
    zinfo = self.getinfo(name)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\zipfile.py", line 905, in getinfo
    'There is no item named %r in the archive' % name)
KeyError: "There is no item named 'OEBPS\\\\toc.ncx' in the archive"
```

items.title: Implement API to add bindings
items.body: Implement API to add bindings in content.opf, as specified [here](http://www.idpf.org/epub/30/spec/epub30-publications.html#sec-bindings-elem), maybe run plugins before writing opf file

items.title: Dynamically chapters
items.body:
In your examples, i see that you references three times every chapter:
add_item, toc (here as a tuple) and spine.

I want to add dynamically chapters from some databases but i dont know how to do that.

Actually, i use https://code.google.com/p/python-epub-builder/source/browse/trunk/ez_epub.py and just call __addSection and it add the section to the ebook, toc and spike, maybe ebooklib can do something like that.

i really want to move to ebooklib because is more functionally and have active developer

thanks for your time, 
regards

items.title: Subchapthers example
items.body:
Can you put some example to create an epub with subchapters?
Please, Regards

items.title: Parse EPUB2 guide
items.body: The EPUB2 guide element of the OPF file is not parsed when an EPUB file is loaded.

items.title: Cover image item
items.body: When an EPUB3 manifest is loaded, the item with cover-image property assigned is not recognized as the cover image.

items.title: Load navigation document
items.body: When reading an EPUB file, if the NCX file is not present the TOC structure should be obtained by parsing the NAV document instead.

items.title: Head and body elements missing in some cases
items.body: If the original document has empty body with no children, body and head elements will be missing from the generated content.

items.title: A typo in the nav item string representation.
Spurious metadata entry while parsing the OPF file.
items.body: When metadata found inside the OPF file is parsed, a bogus entry is read and placed in the book's metadata container.

items.title: Faulty navigation points in the NCX
items.body: Navigation points in the NCX documents that correspond to book sections have an empty URL assigned for content.  This in reported as error by the epubcheck program.

items.title: Book title and UID fields not assigned when reading from file
items.body: When reading an EPUB from a file, the book title and its UID fields are not updated. As this information is contained in the metadata, make sure that it is also assigned to corresponding fields.

items.title: The EPUB folder name is not configurable.
items.body: The default folder name is hard-coded in the container's XML template and will not reflect the name assigned for the book.

items.title: Implement document type
items.body: It would be handy to have Document type also. We should be able to know "this is html document" but we should also know if it is cover.xhtml, nav.xhtml or just another chapter.

items.title: We must not use .wait() for waiting Popen to end
items.body: We _must_ use communicate. Here is a little tip... Read documentation and look at the big red boxes in the documentation.

items.title: Plugin which cleans content with Tidy HTML
items.body:
We need standard plugin which will use tidy to clean chapter content before they are saved in EPUB.
- standard tidy
- https://github.com/w3c/tidy-html5

items.title: Support for guide
items.body:
Implement API and create guide element in the manifest. Guide is deprecated feature, but we should be able to support it. We should also be able to support landmark feature: http://www.idpf.org/epub/30/spec/epub30-contentdocs.html#sec-xhtml-nav-def-types-landmarks

Guide

  1. Table of Contents
  2. List of Illustrations
  3. Start of Content
Example of deprecated guide: Guide support different types: - cover - title-page - toc - index - glossary - acknowledgements - bibliography - colophon - copyright-page - dedication - epigraph - foreword - loi - lot - notes - preface - text

items.title: Implement API to add files which are not present in the manifest
items.body:
There is a need to add files which are not present in the manifest (for instance - iTunesMetadata.plist, META-INF/com.apple.ibooks.display-options.xml).

Probably have it as it is right now but have argument .add_item(item, manifest=False).

items.title: Delete temporary directory
items.body: Somehow temporary directory with unextracted epub ended up in the repository. I wonder who has put it inside.

items.title: Mime type is not correctly guessed when adding items
items.body: Like the title said, mime type is not correctly gussed. mimetype.guess_type can return string OR tuple. We are only handling if it returns tuple. End result is value None for our mime type.

items.title: Implement new API for Plugins
Put parsing function in the utils module
items.body: We are using HTML5 parser way too many times. Just put it in the utils module.

items.title: Basic plugin for filtering non HTML5 content
items.body:
We need a basic plugin which will be able to filter out most of non HTML5 tags, attributes and things like that.

What we would need later is also replace non supported tags with new syntax. For instance, replace <u> tag with element and css and etc...etc.....

items.title: Move common functions to ebooklib.utils
items.body: There are some common functionality which should really be in ebooklib.utils. Things like debug, parse, ....

items.title: Use six package for Python2/Python3 compatibility
items.body: Just use six package to make it work better on Python2/Python3.

items.title: Do not create new title tag in chapter if it already exists
items.body: When creating chapter content we do two things. We copy old tags from the original document and we also add new title tag. We should not add new tag if it already exists. But also, we should not set empty title (if it is not defined) if it already exists.

items.title: Add additional item types for audio and video files
items.body: Add different item types like ITEM_AUDIO and ITEM_VIDEO.

items.title: Implement different methods for fetching different items from a book
items.body: Implement call like get_link_of_href  to fetch item from a book. The question is, should it return just one item or it should return more then one item. I guess more useful would be just to return one item.

items.title: Make some function names more pythonic + update docs + update examples
items.body: writeEPUB and readEPUB should really be write_epub and read_epub.

items.title: Creating EPUB files does not work in Python 3.3
items.body: Issue with string with lxml parse function and dictionary iteritems method.

items.title: Make it work on Python 2.7 / Python 3.3
items.body: Will need to change couple of API calls. This will make library work on Python 2.7 minimal.

items.title: Remove dependency of itertools module
items.body: No need for this. Just use normal generator expression.

items.title: Extend API with methods for filtering data
items.body: Implement methods for fetching and filtering data in book or chapter.

items.title: Handle properties in manifest file when writing to epub
items.body: Handle properties tag when creating epub file.

items.title: Decode filenames when reading them from zip file
items.body: We should unquote filenames when reading them from zip file.

items.title: Read linear flag from spine structure
items.body:
Read and store linear value from spine structure.
<spine toc="ncx">
 <itemref idref="test" linear="no" />
</spine>

items.title: EpubCoverHtml should extend EpubHtml and use it for processing HTML
items.body: We have separate cover template and we used duplicated methods for the same thing. Just extend EpubHtml and use its methods for processing HTML.

items.title: Cover file should also extend EpubHtml class
items.body: It would be best if Cover file also extends EpubHtml. It would be possible to add dynamically other CSS files or JavaScript files with API.

items.title: Navigation xhtml file should behave like other xhtml files
items.body: Navigation xhtml file should extend standard xhtml chapter file class. Also, we should be able to use nav.add_item() to add CSS style definitions. For now, it was just hard coded.

items.title: Item in spine could have flag linear
items.body: We need to support linear flag in spine. The best would be to have option in Item and to be able to mark it somehow when defining spine.

items.title: Do not use ZIP_STORED for every item in zip file
items.body: For unknown reasons we are using ZIP_STORED flag for every single item in zip file. We should use it only for mimetype file.

items.title: Preserve XML declaration when creating XML files
items.body:
We do not preserve XML declarations with creating XML files. What we should so is use option xml_declaration when using etree.tostring function.

Example:
tree_str = etree.tostring(tree, pretty_print=True, encoding='utf-8', xml_declaration=True)
